Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to continue Carnegie Mellon University participation in the CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program to prepare highly-qualified Cybersecurity professionals for entry into the government workforce. This project will prepare the nation?s cybersecurity workforce through advanced studies with interdisciplinary strengths in engineering, computer science, humanities, management and policy, as defined by the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Workforce Framework. It will support 4 cohorts of students, each comprised of approximately seven students with a technical focus in the Master of Science in Information Security Technology and Management program and up to four students with a policy focus in the Master of Science in Information Security Policy and Management program. This program will require a course in ethics for all CyberCorps® SFS students and a project in cybersecurity, either as part of their formal curriculum or through a research assistantship.
The NSF?s CyberCorps® SFS program funds projects that address Cybersecurity education and workforce development. The Scholarship Track provides funding to award scholarships to students in Cybersecurity. In return for their scholarships, recipients will work after graduation for a Federal, State, Local, or Tribal Government organization in a position related to Cybersecurity for a period equal to the length of the scholarship. The Capacity Track seeks innovative proposals leading to an increase in the ability of the United States higher education enterprise to produce Cybersecurity professionals.

To date, the U.S. federal government has hired 148 Carnegie Mellon CyberCorps® SFS graduates who have gone on to serve and protect the nation?s information infrastructure at the Department of Defense, National Security Agency, Federally Funded Research and Development Centers (FFRDC) and many other federal organizations. Carnegie Mellon has earned three national Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) designations in the areas of Information Assurance, Research and Cyber Operations. Leading cybersecurity researchers, investigators and teaching faculty work side by side with the CyberCorps® SFS students to explore and advance critical areas such as software security, cryptography, reverse engineering, privacy, biometrics and cyber forensics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through its participation in the federal CyberCorps Scholarship for Service (SFS) program, Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) is committed to strengthening and defending our nation's critical information infrastructure. Students participating in the SFS program at CMU (SFS@CMU) have access to leading educational programs in information security as well as hands-on learning through campus research in engineering and computer science. This report describes the university's dedication to SFS, which includes enhancing recruitment efforts, advancing research and providing students with a rich variety of federal job opportunities.

 

Intellectual Merit: Under award #1433690, CMU provided funding to 60 full-time equivalent SFS students enrolled in master's degree programs in two highly ranked colleges: the College of Engineering's Information Networking Institute (INI) and the H. John Heinz III College (HNZ). The SFS@CMU scholars interacted with security experts across the university through rigorous, technical coursework and hands-on projects. Faculty from Carnegie Mellon CyLab and the CERT Division of the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) teach SFS students through core courses and provide ample opportunities to participate in cutting-edge cybersecurity research. All SFS@CMU students must successfully complete a cybersecurity or information assurance project prior to graduation, allowing them to gain more in-depth knowledge in specific areas of security.

 

In addition to completing projects, many SFS@CMU students pursue specialized learning through coursework in the Cyber Forensics and Incident Response (CyFIR) Track. Students enrolled in the INI's M.S. in Information Security (MSIS) program also have the option to earn a Cyber Operations (Cyber Ops) certificate, a specialization in high demand within areas of the government, including the National Security Agency (NSA).

 

The SFS@CMU program enhanced its ethics requirement in 2019 to better equip students with the critical-thinking and decision-making skills needed for success in government cybersecurity roles. All SFS@CMU students must complete an approved ethics course as well as lead a discussion on ethical case studies during the SFS Seminar, a required weekly course. Through the SFS Seminar, students also received targeted career guidance, participated in skill-building workshops, and engaged with their SFS peers, graduates and visiting employers, many of whom are SFS@CMU alumni.

 

Broader Impact: The SFS@CMU program continues to enhance its long-term strategies to recruit highly qualified undergraduate students from around the country with relationship-building at other universities, in particular Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBSUs) and Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs). The SFS@CMU program also seeks to attract talented CMU undergraduates from the School of Computer Science (SCS), Information Systems and Public Policy, and the College of Engineering.

 

Over the duration of this award, CMU has participated in a number of diversity-focused conferences and events, including the Grace Hopper Women in Computing Conference, Executive Women's Forum Conference, Women in Cyber Security Conference, ACM Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing Conference, the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers Conference and the National Society for Black Engineers. Outreach through these events, along with personalized communication, have led to greater diversity among applicants.

 

Since 2001, the SFS@CMU program has successfully graduated and placed over 200 students who have gone on to fill vital cybersecurity positions in our nation's cyber workforce. The SFS@CMU program will continue to showcase its strengths to communities of interest through its designated website, marketing efforts, and outreach activities geared towards building the next generation of government-focused cybersecurity professionals.
